description: From Late Latin additivus, from the participial stem of Latin addere (“to add”).

adjectives.description: additive (comparative more additive, superlative most additive)

entries.meaning: (mathematics) Pertaining to addition; that can be, or has been, added.
(mathematics, of a function, etc.) That is distributive over addition.
examples:
Matrix multiplication is additive, in that 
  
    
      
        M
        
          
            
              v
              →
            
          
        
        +
        M
        
          
            
              w
              →
            
          
        
        =
        M
        (
        
          
            
              v
              →
            
          
        
        +
        
          
            
              w
              →
            
          
        
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle M{\vec {v}}+M{\vec {w}}=M({\vec {v}}+{\vec {w}})}
  
.

entries.meaning: (group theory, of a group, semigroup, etc.) Whose operator is identified as addition.
examples: It is natural to look at a finite cyclic group as an additive group.

entries.meaning: (genetics) Of or pertaining to genes (or the interaction etc. of such genes) which govern the same trait and whose effects work together on the phenotype.
A substance added to another substance or product to produce specific properties in the combined substance.
examples: Oil may be used as an additive in gasoline to improve the lubrication of a small engine.

entries.meaning: (grammar) A word or phrase that adds something, such as also, even, or nor.
